executive_summary: Demand for electronic article surveillance (EAS) products has endured losses over recent years. The pandemic significantly impacted the retail sector, the largest market for these products. Stay-at-home orders and rising demand for online retailers discouraged consumers from shopping in brick-and-mortar stores, a trend that remained prominent as the economy reopened. Similarly, a falling crime rate has discouraged retailers from implementing and updating their security systems, as stores feel like theft becomes less likely. As a result, revenue has been falling at an estimated CAGR of 0.2% to $669.0 million over the past five years, including a 0.6% decline in 2023 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Men's and women's clothing stores, the largest consumers of Electronic Article Surveillance (EAS) products, have seen a decline in sales amid weakening consumer spending and rising inflation. Strong preferences favoring online retailers have led to a weakening need for surveillance products, as traditional brick-and-mortar stores have a higher need for these products. The 2020 pandemic enhanced this trend, as most nonessential traditional retailers were required to pause operations to prevent the spread of the virus. The lack of need for EAS products in online sales due to the absence of physical shoplifting threats has negatively affected the performance and revenue of the EAS industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Trade Activity is on the Rise
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Exports from Mexico and China have weakened due to e-commerce growth and a strengthening US dollar, with the majority being shipped to Mexico and Canada. Demand for EAS has been rising at a global level, boosting foreign production and resulting in heightened competition.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Falling Crime Leads to Weaker Demand for EAS Systems
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Property crime constitutes a large portion of all US crime, creating a persistent need for retailers to protect their inventory through EAS technologies. The crime rate has been continuously falling over recent years. The shift toward online retail over traditional brick-and-mortar stores also contributes to reduced shoplifting and thus decreased demand for EAS products. Despite these changes, shoplifting and employee theft continue to be significant concerns for retailers, sustaining some level of demand for EAS systems.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Profit Weakens Amid Volatile Operating Costs
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: EAS products have experienced weaker profit amid rising spending in wages and volatile input prices. Significant supply chain disruptions over recent years led to a shortage and caused semiconductor prices to rise for the first time in decades. Wages as a share of revenue have expanded over recent years as manufacturers allocate more resources toward research and development capabilities, as these require highly skilled workers. Despite these challenges, large companies maintain higher profits as they leverage vertical integration to reduce production costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE GROWING POPULARITY OF ONLINE RETAILERS IS LIKELY TO CAUSE MAJOR MARKETS TO SHIFT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Improving economic conditions are expected to lead to rising disposable income. When consumers feel confident about the future of the economy, they are more likely to boost spending on new clothing and other nonessential items. A pickup in sales is estimated to boost demand for electronic article surveillance (EAS) systems as retailers aim to diminish losses. Although this trend is expected to boost discretionary purchases, the growing online preference is expected to harm revenue growth. Manufacturers will likely seek to add value to their products through the incorporation of enhanced functionality, such as inventory data collection, enabling the manufacturing sector to generate higher revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CHANGING MACROECONOMIC FACTORS ARE EXPECTED TO IMPACT DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Fortunately for EAS product manufacturers, theft will always threaten retailers' profitability. However, an aging population and an improving economy will likely continue to reduce the crime rate over the coming years. The crime rate is expected to decline. As crime becomes less of a threat, retailers will not likely be as pressured to implement or expand their EAS systems, weakening EAS product sales. Improving economic conditions at the global level is expected to lead to the depreciation of the US dollar, making domestically produced products more attractive for both the US and global markets. A weaker dollar is likely to cause imports to slow down while exports gain traction globally, although imports will remain competitive due to their lower production costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STABILIZING INPUT PRICES ARE LIKELY TO BOOST PROFIT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Innovation and high competition among semiconductor manufacturers are expected to persist in the near future, enabling the price of semiconductors to continue declining. The price of plastic materials and resin will likely remain closely linked to movements in the price of crude oil, making it highly volatile. As the price of electronic components continues to weaken, manufacturers' purchasing costs are expected to fall, making manufacturers more profitable.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures electronic article surveillance (EAS) products, which are used to help retailers protect merchandise from theft. Types of EAS technologies include magnetic, acousto-magnetic, radio-frequency and microwave systems. Installation services and devices installed at the manufacturing level for purely logistical purposes (source tagging) are excluded from this report.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retailers are the largest market for electronic article surveillance (EAS) products, as they aim to prevent shoplifting and loss of inventory. Although EAS systems were previously expensive to buy and maintain, technological advances have enabled them to become more affordable, making EAS systems practical for large retailers as well as some small independent retailers.

Other major markets for the industry include commercial, institutional, industrial and governmental organizations. These organizations may similarly deal with employees attempting to steal merchandise, equipment or goods from within. Public buildings like museums may want to protect rare artifacts and artwork from being stolen.

Manufacturers are increasingly source tagging, which is to attach RFID tags to apparel as a part of the manufacturing process to increase value added by making the implementation of EAS systems more convenient. Manufacturers may also deal with expensive materials, like metals, and will want to monitor the influx of input goods and prevent employee theft with EAS products.

products_and_services.product_description: Electromagnetic (EM) systems, also called magnetic systems, work similarly to RF systems but use a different part of the electromagnetic spectrum to communicate. The tags are activated using demagnetization and deactivated using magnetization.

Radio-frequency (RF) systems work by installing an antenna at a store entrance, which creates a narrow, low frequency electromagnetic field. When a tag or label enters this field, it causes the antenna to alarm. To deactivate disposable RF tags, the tag is waved over a high-energy transmitter at the checkout counter that blows a built-in fuse and partially deactivates the tag.

Acousto-magnetic (AM) systems are one of the newest EAS systems and work similarly to RF systems, but when the tag or label enters the field, it vibrates and is picked up by the antenna. These vibrations enable systems to cover wide exits and enable high-speed label application. The transmitter sends a radio frequency signal (58 kHz) in pulses. When the pulse ends, the tag responds and sends out a frequency. To deactivate disposable AM tags, the tag is demagnetized at the checkout counter.

The microwave system is one of the oldest EAS products and is not as accurate as the other systems. These tags are permanent, making them relatively expensive. At an exit, one antenna emits a low-frequency field at about 100 kHz, and another exit releases a microwave field. The tag works to mix the signals from both exits and triggers the alarm.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The retail sector represents a major market for electronic article surveillance products. Ranging between apparel and alcohol, retailers use electronic surveillance devices to reduce shrinkage and protect their inventories. Demand from this sector drives revenue for the industry.

Producers face some competition from alternative theft deterrents, such as cameras and security guards. However, these products and services cannot fully substitute electronic article surveillance products.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Retail Trade Growth in 2023
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand from retail trade is expected to grow in 2023, representing a potential opportunity for the industry.

The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of countries that trade with the United States. As the dollar depreciates, US exports become more attractive, boosting revenue. In contrast, when the US dollar appreciates, there is greater import competition and exports are relatively less competitive in the global market. The TWI is expected to swell in 2023.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Price of Plastic Materials and Resin
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Plastic represents a major input for many surveillance products. If input prices rise, manufacturers must find a balance between competitive prices and growing profit. Recent supply chain disruptions and heightened demand for manufactured products have led to rising plastic prices. The price of plastic materials and resin is expected to increase in 2023.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Price of Semiconductor and Electronic Components
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Semiconductors and electronic components are crucial to the development of surveillance products. Competitive conditions and technological development in semiconductor manufacturing have driven prices for electronic components down. However, recent supply chain disruptions and heightened demand for semiconductors have led to rising prices. The price of semiconductors and other electronic components is expected to expand in 2023, posing a potential threat to the industry.

The crime rate represents the total reported violent and property crimes per 100,000 people. Crime is one of the major motivations for investment into electronic article surveillance products, as electronic surveillance products for articles of inventory are designed mainly to deter theft and reduce associated shrinkage. As the economy continues improving, the crime rate is expected to decrease in 2023.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Changes in Consumer Behavior Cause Imports to Fall
international_trade_points.trade_description: US consumers are increasingly opting to purchase products online as this option is convenient and offers consumers the ability to compare product features. As more consumers opt for online retailers, demand for imported EAS products weakens, weakening demand for imports and causing them to satisfy a smaller portion of domestic demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Domestic Producers Aim to Compete with More Affordable Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Lower operating costs overseas make foreign EAS systems more affordable for buyers, encouraging downstream users to import these products. Countries like Mexico and China benefit greatly from these lower operating costs, making them the largest producers of imported products.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Global Demand Protects Exports from Drastic Drops
international_trade_points.trade_description: Improving economic conditions benefiting global economies has enabled demand for retailers to rise, boosting electronic article surveillance (EAS) product sales. Exports suffered a significant decline during the 2020 pandemic, as trade activity of nonessential products remained subdued. However, the growth in e-commerce has enabled exports to recover.

Over recent years, the dollar has appreciated significantly because of economic instability in other global economies caused by the pandemic and the Ukraine War. A strong US dollar has made domestic products comparatively more expensive overseas, causing demand for exports to slow down.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Environmental regulations include the US Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act. These regulations establish workplace standards and limitations on the discharge of pollutants into the environment and standards for the handling, generation, emission, release, treatment, storage and disposal of certain materials, substances and waste.

Microwave transmitting devices must comply with standards by the FCC. These standards specify permitted frequency bands of operation, permitted power output and periods of operation. New microwave systems must be tested for compliance with FCC standards.

Electronic article surveillance product producers seek to protect their technologies through patent applications in the United States and other countries. Patents prevent other companies from producing protected devices, giving manufacturers a competitive advantage. Patent protection lasts 14 years for designs and 20 years for a manufactured product.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Input Prices Have Been on the Rise
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases, the industry's largest costs, consist of plastic resin and electronic components. Raw materials include plastic, steel, copper and aluminum. The price of oil-based plastics and metals is volatile and has increased as demand from developing countries escalates and as these finite resources are depleted.

Profit has weakened over recent years, accounting for an estimated 6.1% of revenue in 2023, inching down from 6.2% in 2018. Weakening revenue and rising operating costs, mainly in the form of wages, have led to shrinking profit.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Since producers consistently create new products and technologies, manufacturers invest heavily in research and development capabilities, making them highly reliant on employees and boosting labor intensity.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Weakening Demand for Downstream Buyers Harms Manufacturers
volatility_points.volatility_description: Consumers are increasingly opting for online retailers, as they offer convenient solutions and extensive product information. This trend was enhanced during the pandemic when consumers were required to stay at home to prevent the spread of the virus. This growth in demand for online retailers has weakened demand for traditional retailers, harming one of the largest downstream markets of electronic article surveillance (EAS) products.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Volatile Input Prices Force Producers to Pass Down Cost Increases
volatility_points.volatility_description: Manufacturers are susceptible to changes in input prices, including the price of plastic, resin, metals and electronic components. Significant supply chain disruptions and elevated demand for manufactured products during the pandemic led to higher input prices. Manufacturers absorbing these cost increases become less profitable and, therefore, slightly less competitive. However, passing down cost increases to consumers is challenging.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Domestic manufacturers often struggle to compete on the basis of price with low-cost imports. Diversifying products may give domestic producers a competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Although EAS system manufacturers are not directly affected by fluctuations in macroeconomic factors, these fluctuations impact retailers, which are major downstream markets.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The prices of semiconductors and plastic materials vary greatly with the price of crude oil, altering input costs for the EAS Systems manufacturing industry.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Major manufacturers, like Johnson Controls (formerly Tyco) and CCL (formerly Checkpoint Systems), actively participate in M&A activity to expand their market share.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, such as [example: RFDI tags, etc.], in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Although technology in this system has largely stagnated, some producers may still manufacture out-of-date microwave-technology-based EAS systems.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Increasing automation in the manufacturing process increases production efficiencies.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Many other manufacturing industries have tried to be more energy-efficient or environmentally friendly.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: There are very few tariffs protecting this industry from import penetration.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Manufactures face volatile input prices. Producers can attempt to pass on price increases by charging higher prices for their products.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Revenue fluctuates seasonally, increasing over the second half of the year as consumers shop more over the holiday season.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor new environmental regulations? What processes do you have in place to ensure company procedures conform to relevant regulations?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers face a range of regulations regarding the generation and disposal of hazardous wastes. Failure to meet compliance can increase operating costs.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? How many of your clients were referred to you by a satisfied client?
FAQs.answer: The ability to control quality and minimize faulty products reaching the market will help increase brand loyalty through perceived reliability.

FAQs.question: Do you outsource parts of your operation? How do you ensure that outsourcing does not have a negative influence on product and service quality?
FAQs.answer: Many US companies have manufacturing operations overseas. Such outsourcing reduces operating costs by leveraging supply chain efficiencies, low-cost labor and reduced compliance standards.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in the value of the US dollar affected demand for your products? How to you adapt to these fluctuations?
FAQs.answer: When the US dollar appreciates, foreign-produced products are more affordable relative to domestically produced ones. Companies must adapt pricing strategies to remain competitive when the dollar appreciates.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating plastic prices affect your company? How do you monitor changes in the price of plastic materials and resin?
FAQs.answer: The price of plastic materials and resin fluctuates largely with the price of crude oil. Companies often pass on costs by increasing product prices.

FAQs.question: Do you have contracts with large-scale retail dealers? How do you build and maintain strong client relationships?
FAQs.answer: Negotiating long-term contracts and building strong client relationships is beneficial for establishing a good reputation and winning over consumers.
